tn.text: Moses continues the speech to the people of Israel he began in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:05:01|5:1]]. Beginning in verse 2, he speaks to the people of Israel as if they were one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"might obey ... to obey"
"going to the other side of the Jordan River"

tn.ref: that your days may be prolonged
tn.text: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. This can be stated in active form. This can be translated similarly to "prolong your days" in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. AT: "that I may prolong your days" or "that I may cause you to live a long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

Here "listen" means to obey, and "them" refers to Yahweh's commandments. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "listen to Yahweh's commandments, statutes, and decrees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"obey them"

tn.ref: a land flowing with milk and honey
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "a land where plenty of milk and honey flow" or "a land that is excellent for cattle and farming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"Our God Yahweh is the one and only God"

tn.ref: with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your might
tn.text: These phrases combined emphasize that a person is supposed to love God completely and to be totally dedicated to him.
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Moses is speaking God's commandments to the people of Israel.
This is an idiom. AT: "you must always remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: you will diligently teach ... you will talk
tn.text: "I command you to diligently teach ... I command you to talk." The reader should understand these as commands.
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

This is a metonym for "write these words on parchment, put the parchment in a pouch, and tie the pouch." This metonym in turn may be a metaphor for "obey these words so that it is as if they were physically there." AT: "tie these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: as a sign upon your hand
tn.text: "as something to make you remember my laws"

This is a metonym for "write these words on parchment, put the parchment in a pouch, and tie the pouch to your head so it sits." This metonym in turn may be a metaphor for "obey these words so that it is as if they were physically there." AT: "my words will serve as frontlets"(See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
ornaments a person wears on the forehead
This is a command.
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: large and very good cities that you did not build
tn.text: All these cities will belong to the people of Israel when they conquer the people in Canaan.

tn.ref: out of the house of bondage
tn.text: Here the metonym "house of bondage" refers to Egypt, the place where the people of Israel had been slaves. AT: "out of the place where you were slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: You will honor Yahweh your God; him you will worship, and you will swear by his name
tn.text: "It is Yahweh your God and no one else whom you will honor; it is he alone whom you will worship, and it is by his name and only his name that you will swear." Your language may have another way of emphasizing that Yahweh is telling the Israelites not to worship or serve any other god.

tn.ref: you will swear by his name
tn.text: To swear by the name of Yahweh means to make Yahweh the basis or the power on which the oath is made. The metonym "his name" refers to Yahweh himself. AT: "you will swear and ask Yahweh to confirm it" or "when you swear you will speak his name" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"who lives among you"

tn.ref: the anger of Yahweh your God will be kindled against you
tn.text: Moses compares Yahweh's anger to someone starting a fire to destroy things. This can be stated in active form. To kindle anger is a metaphor for becoming very angry. AT: "Yahweh your God will kindle his anger" or "Yahweh your God will become very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"destroy you so that there is nothing left of you anywhere on"
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "test" means to challenge Yahweh and force him to prove himself.
This is the name of a place in the desert. The translator may add a footnote that says: "The name 'Massah' means 'testing.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: You will do what is right and good in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: This idiom is a command and a blessing. If the Israelites obey Yahweh, they will receive blessings from Yahweh. AT: "Do what Yahweh says is right and good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: What are the covenant decrees ... commanded you
tn.text: This question is a metonym. AT: "What do the covenant decrees ... commanded mean to you" or "Why should you obey the covenant decrees ... commanded you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the children of the adult people of Israel to whom Moses was speaking Yahweh's words.
Here "a mighty hand" refers to Yahweh's power. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:34|4:34]]. AT: "with his mighty power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the metonym "his house" refers to the people of Yahweh. AT: "and on all of his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "eyes" refers to the whole person.  AT: "where we could see them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "might bring us into Canaan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Moses continues to tell the people of Israel Yahweh's words as if the Israelites are one person. He tells them what they should tell their children about Yahweh's commandments. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"in the presence of Yahweh" or "where Yahweh can see us"
"obey"
This is a metonym. AT: "he will consider us righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
